title: 103_hr2285
content: The Department of Veterans Affairs Sexual Trauma Counseling Program is outlined in Section 1. The Department of Veterans Affairs extends the period for providing sexual trauma counseling until December 31, 1998. The eligibility period for seeking counseling is also extended, and a limitation on the receipt of counseling is repealed. Section 1720D of title 38, United States Code, is amended by removing subsection (b) and redesignating subsections (c), (d), and (e) as subsections (b), (c), and (d), respectively. Additionally, Section 1712(i) is amended to increase the priority of care for veterans eligible for counseling under section 1720D. Section 1720D of title 38, United States Code, is revised to provide counseling for sexual trauma, with amendments removing gender-specific language and updating section headings and table of sections accordingly. The revised Section 1720D of title 38, United States Code now includes counseling for sexual trauma. The amendments ensure that the telephone system for counseling veterans is operated by trained Department of Veterans Affairs personnel. The revised Section 1720D of title 38, United States Code includes counseling for sexual trauma. Veterans are provided with information on available care and services, referred to appropriate providers, and the telephone system ensures confidentiality. The Secretary ensures the telephone system operates continuously and information about its availability is widely advertised. A report to Congress will detail the number of calls made to the system, including by state, within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will report to Congress on the telephone system, including the number of calls made, types of sexual trauma described, difficulties in obtaining care, training provided to personnel, and recommendations for improvement. The system will commence operation soon. The Secretary will start the telephone system required by law within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 2. REPORT ON SERVICE CONNECTION FOR SEXUAL TRAUMA. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the challenges veterans face in getting determinations from the VA that disabilities related to sexual trauma during active duty are service-connected. The report should also include recommendations for addressing these challenges and preventing failures to recognize such disabilities as service-connected. The term "sexual trauma" refers to physical or psychological trauma from rape, sexual assault, or other acts of sexual violence. The report on challenges veterans face in getting VA determinations for service-connected disabilities related to sexual trauma must be submitted by June 30, 1994. SEC. 3. COORDINATORS OF WOMEN'S SERVICES. The Veterans Health Care Act of 1992 is amended to require full-time service for coordinators of women's services. Additional responsibilities include facilitating communication between women veterans coordinators and higher authorities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure adequate funding, clerical support, and direct access for coordinators of women's services at each facility.
